newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Amoco wants Venezuela tax rule clarified.
newsitem.headline: Amoco wants Venezuela tax rule clarified.

text.p: Value-added tax and dollar accounting procedures for profit-sharing contracts in new oil areas in Venezuela must be clarified soon to avoid jeopardising the process.
"VAT and dollar accounting need to be resolved. These are very serious issues," Amoco President William Lowrie told reporters after addressing an oil conference in Caracas.

Lowrie said failure to resolve the issues could see Amoco and other foreign majors freeze investment in areas purchased by auction in January. "We were told that these things would be taken care of," Lowrie said.

Lowrie was referring to a law approved by Venezuela's congress in July. While the law exempts companies from paying a 16.5 percent tax on the start-up costs of capital intensive projects, the enabling mechanism that supported it was left unformulated and remains hanging.
Dollar accounting means oil companies will not be taxed on unrealised income during the pre-operative stage of exploration and drilling projects.
Under current Venezuelan accounting practices, the value of assets are written-up to keep in line with inflation. The gain in value is then taxed.
Venezuelan inflation over the past 12 months has been over 100 percent.
In January, Amoco acquired interests in two Venezuelan oil blocks, Punta Pescador and Guarapiche. Lowrie noted tax conditions were tough with rates of up to 90 percent.

"The terms and conditions in Venezuela, quite honestly, are tough and its going to take large discoveries to make these economics work," he said. But he added that Amcoco's operations in Venezuela would "add value to shareholders" and that "when a company like Amoco looks at a country like Venezuela it doesn't just look at the fiscal situation."
